paragraphs.context: ̈ Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso do Sul (UFMS) is a Brazilian federal public higher education institution based in Campo Grande , in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul. . Taking the campus of Campo Grande as the center of a hypothetical circle, UFMS covers an extensive geographical and educational area that results in a radius of more than 500 km, reaching about 100 municipalities and including neighboring states and countries, such as Paraguay and Bolivia, from which part of its students-convenient originate. ̈ In addition to its headquarters in Campo Grande, UFMS maintains campi in nine cities (Aquidauana, South Chapadão, Corumbá, Coxim, Navimáí, Nova Andradina, Paranaíba, Ponta Porã and Three Lagoas) decentralizing education to meet the demand of various regions of the state.

paragraphs.context: . The Federal University of Mato Grosso do Sul (UFMS) originated in 1962, with the creation of the Faculdade de Pharmacia e Odontologia , in Campo Grande, which would be the embryo of public higher education in the south of the then state of Mato Grosso. . On July 26, 1966, through Law No. 2,620, these courses were absorbed with the creation of the Institute of Biological Sciences of Campo Grande, which reformulated the previous structure, instituted departments and created the course of Medicine. In 2014, a course of Medicine was also created in Three Lagoons. . In Corumbá, the State Government created, in 1967, the Higher Institute of Pedagogy and, in Three Lagoons, the Institute of Human Sciences and Letters, thus expanding the higher education network. . With the division of the state of Mato Grosso, the federalization of the institution that became known as the Federal University of Mato Grosso do Sul Foundation was carried out by Federal Law no. 6.674 of 05.07.1979. . The then Rondonópolis Pedagogical Center, based in Rondonópolis - MT, became a member of the Federal University of Mato Grosso (UFMT). . In 2005 the campus of Dourados (CPDO) was dismembered to give rise to the Federal University of the Great Gold with its installation on 01.01.2006, according to Law No. 11,153, of 29.07.2005.

qas.question: . What was the embryo of public higher education in southern Mato Grosso?

paragraphs.context: . Public Universities in Brazil, especially those linked to the Federal System, adopt an organizational model that is characterized by many similarities in which decisions of Collegiate Bodies predominate. . In the case of UFMS, the central administration is given by Reitoria , which is the executive body that manages, directs, coordinates and supervises all university activities. . The position of Rector is exercised by a professor appointed in the form of the law, to execute the decisions of the university's higher collegiate bodies - University Council (COUN); Board of Directors (CD), and Chambers of Education, Research and Graduate and Extension. . The Rector is responsible administratively and legally for all acts within the institution. . This includes the ordering of expenses being responsible to the MEC and the Court of Auditors of the Union for managing the third largest budget of the State. . The Rector is also responsible for bringing the University closer to the community, through agreements and partnerships with other bodies and institutions.

qas.question: . By whom is the central administration of UFMS given?

paragraphs.context: . The National Post-Graduate Computer Entry Examination (POSCOMP) is an exam applied in all regions of the country. . In partnership with the Peruvian Computer Society, the Exame began to be held in Peru since 2006. . POSCOMP tests knowledge in the area of Computers and has as its specific objective to evaluate the knowledge of candidates for Computer Graduate Programs offered in Brazil. . The vast majority of graduate programs in the country use, in some way, the result of the POSCOMP in its selective process.

paragraphs.context: . POSCOMP was designed to allow candidates to participate in the selection processes in various programs in the country, without the need for a relocation to the headquarters of each of the programs nominated by the candidate, thus fulfilling a strong role of social inclusion . . The candidate performs the test in the nearest place where he lives and the result of his exam is sent to all programs that participate in the POSCOMP, thus the candidate can sue vacant in any of the graduate programs that participate in the POSCOMP.

paragraphs.context: . Computer science is the science that studies techniques, methodologies and computational instruments, which automates processes and develops solutions based on the use of digital processing . . It is not limited only to the study of algorithms, their applications and implementation in the form of software, extrapolating to all and any knowledge based on the computer, which also involves telecommunications, the database and technological applications that allow to achieve the processing of input and output data, so that it becomes information. Thus, Computer Science also covers data modelling techniques and communication protocols, as well as principles that cover other specializations in the area.

answers.text: the science that studies techniques, methodologies and computational instruments, which automates processes and develops solutions based on the use of digital processing

qas.question: . What is computer science?

paragraphs.context: . As a science, it is classified as exact science , although it inherits elements of the Aristotelian philosophical logic, having therefore an important role in the mathematical formalization of algorithms, as a way to represent decipherable problems, i.e., those that are susceptible to reduction to basic elementary operations, capable of being reproduced through any mechanical/electronic device capable of storing and manipulating data. . One of these devices is the digital computer, which is widely used today. . Also of fundamental importance for the area of Computer Science are the methodologies and techniques related to software implementation that address the specification, modeling, coding, testing and evaluation of software systems.

C., in ancient India, the grammar Pānini formulated Sanskrit grammar using 3959 rules known as Ashtadhyāyi, in a very systematic and technical way. . Pānini used transformations and recursivity with such sophistication that his grammar possessed the theoretical computational power such as Turing Machine. . Between 200 a. . C. and 400, the Indians also invented logarithm, and from the 13th century logarithm tables were produced by Islamic mathematicians. paragraphs.context: . Around the third century B.C. . C., Indian mathematician Pingala invented the binary numbering system. ▪ Still currently used in the processing of all modern computers, the system establishes that specific sequences of some and zeros can represent any information. . In 1703 Gottfried Leibniz developed logic in a formal and mathematical sense, using the binary system. . In their system, some and zeros also represent concepts like true and false, connected and disconnected, valid and invalid. . More than a century later, George Boole published Boolean algebra (in 1854), with a complete system that allowed the construction of mathematical models for computational processing. . In 1801, the tear, controlled by a punched card, invented by Joseph Marie Jacquard, appeared, in which holes indicated the ones and, unfurled areas, indicated the zeros. . The system is far from a computer, but it illustrated that machines could be controlled by the binary system.

paragraphs.context: . It was with Charles Babbage that the modern computer began to gain form, through its work in analytical engineering. . The equipment originally described in 1837, more than a century before its successor, was never successfully built, but had all the functions of a modern computer. . Babbage's device was differentiated by being programmable, something essential for any modern computer. . During its collaboration, mathematics Ada Lovelace published the first computer programs in a series of notes for analytical engineering. . Therefore, Lovelace is popularly considered the first programmer.

paragraphs.context: . Before the 1920s, computers were a term associated with people who performed calculations, usually led by physicists. . Thousands of computers were employed in projects in trade, government and research sites. ̈ After the 1920s, the expression computer machine began to be used to refer to any machine that performs the work of a professional, especially those according to the methods of Church-Turing thesis. . The term computer machine ended up losing space for the term reduced computer in the late 1940s, with digital machines increasingly widespread. Alan Turing, known as the father of Computer Science, invented the Turing Machine, which later evolved into the modern computer.

paragraphs.context: . The mathematical foundations of modern computer science began to be defined by Kurt Gödel with his theorem of incompleteness (1931). . This theory shows that there are limits to what can be proven or disapproved in a formal system; this led to later works by Gödel and other theorists to define and describe such formal systems, including concepts such as recursivity and lambda calculation. In 1936 Alan Turing and Alonzo Church independently, and also together, introduced the formalization of an algorithm, defining the limits of what can be a computer and a purely mechanical model for computing. . Such topics are addressed in what is currently called Church-Turing's thesis, a hypothesis about the nature of mechanical calculating devices. . This thesis defines that any possible calculation can be performed by an algorithm being executed on a computer, provided there is sufficient time and storage for that.

paragraphs.context: . Turing also included in the thesis a description of the Turing Machine, which has an infinite-sized tape and a head for reading and writing that moves through the tape. . Due to its infinite character , such machine cannot be built, but such model can simulate the computation of any algorithm executed on a modern computer. Turing is quite important for Computer Science, so much so that its name is used for the Turing Prize and Turing Test. . paragraphs.context: . Until the 1930s, electrical engineers could build electronic circuits to solve logical and mathematical problems , but most did so without any process, in particular, without theoretical rigour for such. . This changed with Claude Shannon's 1937 Master's thesis, A Symbolic Analysis of Relay and Switching Circuits. . While taking philosophy classes, Shannon was exposed to the work of George Boole, and realized that he could apply this learning in electromechanical sets to solve problems. . Shannon developed the information theory in the 1948 article: Mathematical Theory of Communication, whose content serves as the basis for areas such as data compression and encryption.

paragraphs.context: . Despite its small history as an academic discipline, Computer Science has given rise to several fundamental contributions to science and to society . . This science was responsible for the formal definition of computation and computability, and for the proof of the existence of insoluble or intractable computational problems. . It was also possible to construct and formalize the concept of computer language, especially programming language, a tool for the precise expression of flexible methodological information enough to be represented at various levels of abstraction. . For other scientific fields and for society in general, Computer Science provided support for the Digital Revolution, giving rise to the Information Age. . Scientific computing is an area of computing that allows the advancement of studies such as mapping the human genome.

paragraphs.context: . Despite the name, much of Computer Science does not involve the study of computers by itself. . The design and development of computers and computer systems are generally considered disciplines outside the context of Computer Science. For example, hardware study is generally considered part of computer engineering, while the study of commercial computational systems is usually part of information technology or information systems.

paragraphs.context: . Sometimes the Computer Science is also criticized for not being sufficiently scientific , as explained in the phrase "Science is for the Computer Science as well as the hydrodynamics is for the construction of plumbing", credits Stan Kelly-Bootle. . Despite this, his study often crosses other fields of research, such as artificial, physical and linguistic intelligence. . It is considered by some to have a great relationship with mathematics, greater than in other disciplines. . This is evidenced by the fact that the first works in the area were strongly influenced by mathematicians such as Kurt Gödel and Alan Turing; the field continues to be useful for the exchange of information with areas such as mathematical logic, category theory and algebra. . Despite this, unlike mathematics, Computer Science is considered a more experimental than theoretical discipline.

paragraphs.context: . In many institutions, the TCC is considered as the final criterion for evaluating the student: in case of failure, the student will be prevented from obtaining the diploma and consequently exercising the respective profession until it is approved. . The scope and format of the TCC (as well as its own nomenclature) vary between the various courses and between different institutions, but in the Brazilian curriculum structure it has a prominent role: in science-related courses, is usually a work involving experimental research , in professional courses, usually involves: bibliographic research and/or empirical, the execution itself and a presentation of a project before an examining bank between 3 and 5 teachers (not necessarily with Master or Doctor). . The examiner bench formed for this purpose does not create any expectation of originality. . Therefore, it may be a compilation (and not a copy) of other essays for a purpose, a conductor wire, or something that provides a script, a continuity.

answers.text: is usually a work involving experimental research

qas.question: . What involves the TCC in science-related courses?

paragraphs.context: . In the year of implementation of a new curriculum matrix, students with expectations of college education by the previous curriculum matrix that year may be enrolled in disciplines without having fulfilled all the prerequisites required for enrolment. . The renewal of registration is composed of three consecutive phases: registration, confirmation and validation . . The registration in the disciplines will be carried out online by the academic, and will consist in the choice of the disciplines listed, respecting the prerequisites. . Confirmation of the registration will be made by the Course Coordination, by presentation, by the academic, of the registration form printed in two ways, on the date provided for in the Academic Calendar, which should be signed by the Coordinator and the academic. . The validation of the registration will be carried out by approval of the Unit Directorate of Sectoral Administration and a path of the document should be archived in the academic folder in the Academic Secretariat. . The renewal of the enrollment will be converted, by Course Coordination, into a lock when there is no offer of disciplines that the academic is able to attend. . The hourly load of optional disciplines of each Course can be completed in the course itself or in any Unit of Sectoral Administration.

Registration in compulsory subjects can be done in the course itself or in any other course of UFMS , provided that there is compatibility between the name of the discipline, issue and time load, by the existence of vacancies. . paragraphs.context: . In a global view, the first university to follow the modern concept emerged in Asia during the fifth century, and was known as the University of Nalanda in Bihar, India. . In it lived the Buddhist philosopher Nagarjuna. . During its existence it has had more than 10,000 students and 1,500 teachers. . The curriculum of this university was extensive and involved areas such as theology, philosophy, mathematics, astronomy, alchemy and anatomy. . His Buddhist philosophers promoted philosophical debates involving various themes. . In 1193 the University of Nalanda was looted by Muslim invaders. When Tibetan translator Chag Lotsawa visited her in 1235, he found her partly destroyed but still functioning with a small number of monks. . The destruction of Nalanda as well as of temples and monasteries in northern India, where there were study centers, is considered by several historians as the cause of the sudden disappearance of ancient Indian scientific thought. . In 670 d. . C. was founded in Tunisia the mosque of Cairuão and began the development of the first Arab university where the Arabic language, theology, Islamic history, Malik jurisprudence, mathematics, astronomy, medicine and botany were taught. . However, a few decades later the mosque of Cairuão was destroyed and its university center was rebuilt in the city of Montfleury in 737 d. . where was then founded the Ez-Zitouna university that works to this day and is considered by many Arabs as the first university.

qas.question: . Where did the first modern university arise?

paragraphs.context: . Public universities are protected by the national or local governments , whose interference in the internal administration of each university may be greater or lesser, according to the country, region or the institution's own statute. . In some cases, universities are directly supervised by the government department of education or higher education, but in other states this guardianship may be delegated to an independent entity, usually of a collegial nature. . Governmental guardianship bodies are usually always responsible for allocating public funds to universities, for accreditation of institutions and their higher education courses and for the degree regime conferred. . In addition to the financial component, depending on the degree of autonomy attributed to universities, guardianship bodies may have interference in the system of access, in the creation, alteration or termination of higher education courses, in the internal organization of institutions, in their university strategic plans and in the regime of teaching staff. . However, a large part of public universities have extensive financial, pedagogical and scientific autonomy.

qas.question: . Who is the custodian of public universities?

These units have greater or lesser autonomy within the university, according to the organization of the university. In the event that their units have a large autonomy , a university may constitute a mere federation of schools or colleges, grouped for purely administrative purposes, possibly sharing some common resources. . Many universities of this type originated in the administrative grouping of older schools, which, even integrated into a larger institution, maintained their identity and part of their autonomy.

answers.text: In the event that their units have a large autonomy

paragraphs.context: . Above all in the USA, but also in some other countries, there is the concept of a university system which constitutes an organization of the dome or federation that groups together with a group of universities and other higher education institutions, usually distributed geographically by various places. . Normally, there is a central body of collective administration of the system, but each constituent university maintains its own particular administration, with greater or lesser autonomy in relation to the central organ. . University systems have become quite common in the USA in the post-Second World War , so that almost all its states have one or more of these systems, under which their public universities are grouped, sharing a name, an administration and some common resources. . Much of the university systems are referred to as "university", each of which is referred to by the name of the system, plus a particular designation (e.g.: . University of California is the public university system of the State of California, which includes the University of California, Los Angeles and the University of California, Berkeley, among others.).

paragraphs.context: . Higher education in Brazil began much earlier, still in the colonial period , with the creation of specialized higher schools, modeled in similar schools existing in the Portuguese Metropolis. . One of the first was the Royal Academy of Artillery, Fortification and Design, created in 1792 in Rio de Janeiro by Queen D. Maria I of Portugal, with the main aim of training military technical officers and engineers. . This Academy is considered to be the first engineering college in the Americas and one of the first in the world, being at the remote origin of the current Military Institute of Engineering and Polytechnic School of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro. . According to the Portuguese model, none of these schools were granted university status, which was reserved throughout the Portuguese Empire for the University of Coimbra (even in Portugal, except for the University of Évora, with a brief existence, the various higher education institutions existing outside Coimbra only achieved university status in 1911).

paragraphs.context: . Higher education in Brazil began much earlier, even in the colonial period, with the creation of specialized higher schools, modelled on similar schools existing in the Portuguese metropolis. . One of the first was the Real Academia de Artillery, Fortification and Design , created in 1792 in Rio de Janeiro by Queen D. Maria I of Portugal, with the main purpose of training technical officers and military engineers. . This Academy is considered to be the first engineering college in the Americas and one of the first in the world, being at the remote origin of the current Military Institute of Engineering and Polytechnic School of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro. . According to the Portuguese model, none of these schools were granted university status, which was reserved throughout the Portuguese Empire for the University of Coimbra (even in Portugal, except for the University of Évora, with a brief existence, the various higher education institutions existing outside Coimbra only achieved university status in 1911).

answers.text: Real Academia de Artillery, Fortification and Design

paragraphs.context: . The technology analyst in systems analysis and development is a professional of a higher level trained in a Higher Course in Technology . . This type of graduation aims to train professionals to attend specific fields of the labour market. . Its format is therefore more compact, with a mean duration shorter than that of traditional undergraduate courses. . As a professional at the higher level, technologists can continue their studies by completing the Stricto sensu (Master and Doctorate) and Lato sensu (Specialization) postgraduate courses. . The current designation of the profession was established by Decree 2208 of 17 April 1997. . Systems analysis is the activity that aims to conduct process studies in order to find the best and most rational way for the information to be processed. . In Brazil, the Regional Board of Administration (CRA), according to the regulations of the Federal Board of Administration (FCA), issues the professional portfolio of System Analysts who have completed the university course with emphasis on System Analysis.

paragraphs.context: . Informatics or Information Technology is an indispensable component in organizations, as technological solutions automate processes and provide competitive advantages through scenario analysis, support to decision-making and the definition and implementation of new organizational strategies. . Thus, concerns about the collection, storage, processing and transmission of information grow, precisely because the availability of the right information is a fundamental requirement for the continuous improvement of organizational quality and competitiveness, which implies considering the growing relevance of computer-based information systems. . An information system can be technically defined as "a set of interrelated components that collects (or recovers), processes, stores and distributes information to support decision-making, coordination and control of an organization. . In addition to supporting decision-making, coordination and control, information systems can also help managers and workers to analyze problems, visualize complex situations, and create new products." ( LAUDON, 2004, p. 7.

paragraphs.context: . Computer Engineering or Computer Engineering is the engineering branch that deals with the design and construction of computers and systems that integrate hardware and software, enabling the production of new machines and computer equipment to be used in various sectors. . Computer is the most well-known computer system. . However, the Computer Engineering course does not focus on the development of personal computers but on computer systems in general. Although the computer is best known, it represents only 20% of the entire computing system in the world, the other 80% being known as "boarded systems", because they are computer systems that are part of a larger system, such as: aircraft and ship onboard computer, monitoring and control systems for plants and industrial plants. . Much of today's electronics are computer systems, because they have advanced microprocessors, firmware and software: TVs, mobile phones, microwaves, refrigerators, etc.

paragraphs.context: . The first course in Brazil to offer undergraduate studies in the field was Systems and Computer Engineering at the Faculty of Engineering at the Universidade Estadual do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ). . Created by decree 466 of December 1976 of the UERJ Higher Council of Education and Research, the course began to work effectively in 1977, as an emphasis of the Electrical Engineering course. . Created in a time when the environment of the computer teaching area was entirely dominated by private entities, this course was one of the pioneers, since there were practically no undergraduate courses focused on systems and computing and the existing opportunities were few and expensive. . The System and Computer Engineering Course then emerged with the aim of meeting the needs of a labour market with a shortage of professionals with higher education in the specific area of computing. . The curriculum of the course was revised in 1986, in 1994 and currently undergoes a review with the aim of making it an independent course of electrical engineering, becoming simply called a degree in Computer Engineering.

answers.text: Systems and Computer Engineering at the Faculty of Engineering at the Universidade Estadual do Rio de Janeiro

paragraphs.context: MIT's model is that of Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE) - which created the degree in Computer Engineering in a partnership between the Computer Science Center and the Department of Electronics and Systems - also maintaining the original Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, the Federal University of Ouro Preto (UFOP), which is based on a campus in João Monlevade, with still untrained classes and the Federal University of Itajubá (UNIFEI) - which follows the same trend of MIT, has joined the institutes of electrical and computer sciences to give rise to the bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering. . A different case was that of the Federal University of São Carlos (UFSC), which had two modalities of the Computer Science course: one with software emphasis and the other with hardware emphasis. . In this case, the original Bachelor's course was maintained with software emphasis, and the course with hardware emphasis was transformed into the Computer Engineering course. . Currently (2006), a new curriculum was proposed and today the course is a Computer Engineering with emphasis on Control and Automation.

Other recent examples that followed the MIT model are the Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE) - which created the degree in Computer Engineering in a partnership between the Computer Center and the Department of Electronics and Systems - also maintaining the original Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, the Federal University of Black Gold (UFOP), which hosted the course on a campus in João Monlevade, with still untrained classes and the Federal University of Itajubá (UNIFEI) - which following the same trend of MIT, united the institutes of electrical and computer sciences to give rise to the bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering. . A different case was that of Universidade Federal de São Carlos (UFSC), which had two modalities of the Computer Science course: one with software emphasis and another with hardware emphasis. . In this case, the original Bachelor's course was maintained with software emphasis, and the course with hardware emphasis was transformed into the Computer Engineering course. . Currently (2006), a new curriculum was proposed and today the course is a Computer Engineering with emphasis on Control and Automation.

paragraphs.context: . At Universidade Federal do Rio Grande (UFRG), located in Rio Grande, Rio Grande do Sul, the Computer Engineering Course was created in 1993 and had its first entry in 1994, and the first class formed in 1998. . In 2008 it joined the then newly founded Computer Science Center. . In this case, the course, although based on the general positions of teaching and training in Engineering, is not a specialty of Electrical Engineering, but rather a focus on a more focused approach to Computer Science for the computational solution of technical and technological problems, aiming at the autonomous performance of the computer engineer or in conjunction with professionals from other areas of Engineering and other technological or scientific careers. . Currently, after extensive structural reform, besides counting on all the traditional basic training of the courses of Engineering (calculation, physics, drawing, administration etc.), . the curriculum operates under the concept of system, with axes ranging from mathematical foundation and computer science itself (discrete mathematics, data structures, databases, programming languages, algorithm analysis, software engineering, computer theory, etc.), . to the specificities of computer technologies, such as information and programming systems, graphics, intelligent, manufacturing, microprocessed and distributed. . The course "grade" can be consulted on your page. . An approach that the Course had to the aspects of control and automation and concepts of system analysis was greatly diminished from the establishment of the courses of automation engineering and information system at the same University in 2009. . Currently, UFRG has, even, Master's in Computer Engineering, that due to its non-attached genesis, Electrical Engineering is one of the only ones in Brazil associated with the Computing Area Committee in CAPES.

Computer engineering professionals have full training in engineering and a solid technical-scientific and professional training, which enables them to specify, develop, implement, adapt, industrialize, install and maintain computational systems, as well as to perfect the integration of physical and logical resources necessary for meeting informational, computational and automation needs. . Voltage training is back. . In Brazil, a computer engineer is considered to be a graduate in Computer Engineering, but to be able to practice the profession, registration is required in the CREA system (Regional Council of Engineering and Agronomy) of the state where he works. ̈ Professionals can work in educational institutions, banks; the areas for this professional also include the area of civil construction and national security.

answers.text: specify, develop, implement, adapt, industrialize, install and maintain

paragraphs.context: . Software engineering is an area of computer focused on specification, development, maintenance and creation of software, with the application of technologies and practices of project management and other disciplines, aiming at organization, productivity and quality. . These technologies and practices currently include programming languages, databases, tools, platforms, libraries, software design standards, software process and software quality. ̈ In addition, software engineering must offer mechanisms to plan and manage the process of developing a quality computing system that meets the needs of a software requisitor. . The scientific foundations for software engineering involve the use of abstract and precise models that allow the engineer to specify, design, implement and maintain software systems, evaluating and guaranteeing their qualities. . The area that studies and evaluates software engineering processes, proposing the evolution of processes, tools and methods of support to software engineering is Experimental Software Engineering.

answers.text: specification, development, maintenance and creation of

qas.question: . What is the area that studies and evaluates software engineering processes?

paragraphs.context: Friedrich Ludwig Bauer defined it as: "Software Engineering is the creation and use of sound engineering principles in order to obtain software in an economical, reliable and real machine-working way". Margaret Hamilton is credited for creating the term "software engineering". . The very meaning of engineering already brings the concepts of creation, construction, analysis, development and maintenance. . Software Engineering focuses on the practical aspects of software system production, while computer science studies the theoretical foundations of the computational aspects . . The term was created in the 1960s and officially used in 1968 in the NATO Science Committee. . Its creation arose in an attempt to circumvent the software crisis and give an engineering treatment (more systematic, controlled and measurable quality) to the development of complex software systems. . A complex software system is characterized by a set of abstract software components encapsulated in the form of algorithms, functions, modules, objects or interconnecting agents, composing the software architecture, which should be executed in computational systems.

answers.text: the theoretical foundations of the computational aspects

The scientific foundations of software engineering involve the use of abstract and precise models that allow the engineer to specify, design, implement and maintain software systems, evaluating and guaranteeing their quality. . In addition, it should offer mechanisms to plan and manage the development process. . The Federal University of Goiás was a pioneer in Brazil when it created the undergraduate course in Software Engineering, today the course is gaining popularity and is already adopted by other universities such as Federal University of Mato Grosso do Sul, University of Brasilia, Federal Technological University of Paraná, Federal University of Ceará, Federal University of Amazonas, Federal University of Pampa, State University of Ponta Grossa, PUC-Campinas, PUC-RS, Center of Higher Education of Juiz de Fora, among others.

paragraphs.context: . Different different models of computation were proposed by the first researchers. . A model, known as Turing Machine , proposed the construction of a universal machine, capable of operating with a sequence of instructions and data intertwined in an infinite length tape; the machine could operate at one point of the tape at a time using a read and write header, thus performing the programming that is passed to it. . Another model is based on recursive functions composed to operate directly on the numbers. . A similar approach is lambda calculation. . Another class of approaches works with grammatical rules operating on character strings, such as Markov strings and Post systems.

paragraphs.context: . All the formalisms proposed above are equivalent in terms of computational power - that is, any computation that can be performed with a model can be performed with any of the other models. . In theoretical terms, the models proposed are equivalent to the electronic computers , provided there are no memory restrictions involved. . In fact, it is believed that all theoretically possible formalizations for the concept of algorithm are equivalent in power to a Turing machine; this is the Church-Turing thesis. . Questions concerning the possibility of performing certain types of computing in certain types of machine (or theoretical formalism) are investigated by the theory of computation.

paragraphs.context: . In addition to generic computational models, some simpler computational models are useful for more restricted applications. . Regular expressions, are used for example to specify character string patterns, being popular in UNIX applications and in some programming languages, such as Perl and Python . . Another mathematically equivalent formalism to regular expressions is finite automatons, which are used in circuit design and in some problem solving systems. . Context-free grammars are used to specify the syntax of programming languages; equivalent formalism is automatons with stack, or automatic pushdown. . Primitive recursive functions form a subclass of recursive functions.

The request for the Home Exercises Scheme must be immediately registered to to verify the fact, and the request with retroactive value is rendered ineffective, because it decharacterizes the purpose of the scheme. . The period of commencement of the home exercise scheme by the date of the application protocol and the final period by the date set out in the medical report will therefore be counted. . The referral of the application for a home exercise scheme shall be made to the Course Coordinator or equivalent, on the basis of the medical report submitted. . In the event of any doubts regarding the framework of the medical report in the home exercise regime, the Course Coordinator or equivalent should consult the Official Medical Board of UFMS. . paragraphs.context: ▪ The UFMS/PROGRAD issue no 163, dated June 19, 2018, aims at the selection process of disciplines that will obtain monitors in the scholarship and volunteer categories for the second semester of 2018 in each Unit of UFMS Sectoral Administration. . The UFMS will make available through this Editorial the amount of R$ 220,800.00 (two hundred and twenty thousand royal ones) for the grant of 138 scholarships. . The institutional grant is a monthly grant paid and granted by UFMS only to the student participating in the Program. . The scholarship has the value of R$ 400.00 (four hundred real) monthly, and the 12 hours weekly regime is established. . paragraphs.context: . Computer is a machine capable of various types of automatic data processing or data processing. . A computer can have numerous attributes, including data storage, data processing, large-scale calculation, industrial design, graphic image processing, virtual reality, entertainment and culture. . In the past, the term has already been applied to people responsible for some calculation. . In general, a computer is understood as a physical system that performs some kind of computing. . There is also a rigorous mathematical concept used in computation theory. . Personal computers and laptops were assumed to be icons of the Information Age; and this is what many people consider as "computer". . However, the most common forms of computers currently in use are embedded systems, small devices used to control other devices, such as robots, digital cameras or toys.

answers.text: a machine capable of various types of automatic data processing or

paragraphs.context: John Napier (1550-1617), a Scottish inventor of logarithms, also invented Napier's bones, which were multiplication tables engraved in baton, which avoided the memory of the tabuada. . The first real machine was built by Wilhelm Schickard being able to add, subtract, multiply and divide. . This machine was lost during the Thirty Years War, and recently some documentation was found about it. . For many years nothing was known about this machine, so Blaise Pascal (1623-1662) was attributed to the construction of the first calculator, which made only sums and subtractions. . Pascal machine was created with the aim of helping his father to calculate taxes in Rouen, France. . Pascal's project was greatly improved by German mathematician Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646-1726), who also invented calculus, which he dreamed that, one day in the future, all reasoning could be replaced by turning a simple lever. . All these machines, however, were far from being a computer of general use, because they were not programmable. . This means that the entry was made only of numbers, but not of instructions regarding what to do with the numbers.

paragraphs.context: . The origin of the idea of programming a machine comes from the need for weaving machines to produce different color patterns. . Thus, in the 18th century a way was created to represent the patterns in perforated paper cards, which were treated manually. . In 1801, Joseph Marie Jacquard (1752-1834) invented a mechanical tear, with an automatic card reader. . Jacquard's idea crossed the Channel, where he inspired Charles Babbage (1792-1871), a Cambridge math teacher, to develop a "number-tecting" machine, a calculating machine where the way of calculating could be controlled by cards. . It all began with the attempt to develop a machine capable of calculating polynomials by means of differences, the differential calculator. . While designing his differential calculator, Jacquard's idea made Babbage imagine a new and more complex machine, the analytical calculator, machine with some elements that refer to current computers.

paragraphs.context: . The first electromechanical computer was built by Konrad Zuse (1910-1995). . In 1936, this German engineer built, from relays that performed the calculations and data read on perforated tapes , the Z1. . Zuse tried to sell the computer to the German government, which despised the offer, since it would not help in the war effort. . Zuse's projects would stand still during the war, giving Americans the chance to develop their computers. . It was in World War II that the current computers were really born. . The United States Navy, together with Harvard University, developed the Harvard Mark I computer, designed by Professor Howard Aiken, based on Babbage's analytical calculator. . Mark I occupied approximately 120m3, and was able to multiply two digits in three seconds. . Simultaneously, and secretly, the United States Army was developing a similar project, led by engineers J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly, whose result was the first valve computer, the Electronic Numeric Integrator And Calculator (ENIAC), capable of making five hundred multiplications per second. . Having been designed to calculate ballistic trajectory, ENIAC was kept secret by the American government until the end of the war, when it was announced to the world.

answers.text: from relays that performed the calculations and data read on perforated tapes

paragraphs.context: . Even though the technology used in digital computers has changed dramatically since the early 1940s , almost all current computers still use von Neumann's architecture proposed by John von Neumann. . Following the architecture, computers have four main sections, the logical and arithmetic unit, the control unit, the memory and the input and output devices. . These parts are interconnected by buses. . The logical and arithmetic unit, the control unit, the recorders and the basic input and output part are known as the CPU. . Some larger computers differ from the above model in a main aspect - they have multiple CPUs working simultaneously. . In addition, few computers, used mainly for research and scientific computing, have significant differences from the above model, but they do not have great commercial application.

qas.question: . What are the CPU components?

paragraphs.context: . The CPU is one of the main parts of computer hardware and is responsible for calculations, task execution and data processing. . The speed at which the computer performs tasks or processes data is directly linked to the speed of the processor. . The first CPUs were made of several separate components, but since the mid-1970s the CPUs have been manufactured in a single integrated circuit, and are then called microprocessors. . The logical and arithmetic unit (ULA) is the central unit of the processor, which actually performs the arithmetic and logical operations between two numbers. . Its parameters include, in addition to operating numbers, a result, a control unit command, and the state of the command after the operation. . The set of arithmetic operations of an ALU may be limited to addition and subtraction, but may also include multiplication, division, trigonometric functions and square roots. Some can only operate with integers, while others support the use of floating point to represent real numbers (although they have limited accuracy).

paragraphs.context: . The control unit is the processor unit that stores the memory position that contains the current instruction that the computer is executing , informing the ULA which operation to perform, seeking the information (from memory) that the ULA needs to execute it and transferring the result back to the appropriate memory location. . Having done this, the control unit goes to the next instruction (typically located in the next position of memory, unless the instruction is a diversion instruction informing that the next instruction is in another position). ▪ The CPU also contains a restricted set of memory cells called recorders, which can be read and written much faster than on other memory devices. ▪ They are often used to avoid continuous access to the main memory whenever a data is requested.

answers.text: the memory position that contains the current instruction that the computer is executing

paragraphs.context: . Memory is a device that allows the computer to store data for a certain time. . Currently the term is usually used to define volatile memories, such as RAM, but its primordial concept also addresses non-volatile memories, such as hard drive. . Part of the computer memory is made in the processor itself; the rest is diluted in components such as RAM memory, cache memory, hard drive and removable media readers such as floppy disk, CD and DVD. . In modern computers, each memory position is configured to store groups of eight bits (called a byte). . Each byte can represent 256 different numbers; from 0 to 255 or from -128 to +127. . To store larger numbers you can use several consecutive bytes (usually two, four or eight). When negative numbers are stored, the add-on rating for two is used. . Computer memory is usually divided between primary and secondary, and researchers claim to have "third" memory.

In modern computers, each memory position is configured to store groups of eight bits (called a byte). . Each byte can represent 256 different numbers; from 0 to 255 or from -128 to +127. . To store larger numbers you can use several consecutive bytes (usually two, four or eight). When negative numbers are stored, the add-on rating for two is used. . Computer memory is usually divided between primary and secondary, and researchers claim to have "third" memory.

answers.text: numbers you can use several consecutive bytes

paragraphs.context: . Input and output devices (E/S) are peripheral devices used for man-computer interaction. . In modern personal computers, common input devices include mouse, keyboard, scanner and webcam. . Common output devices include sound box, monitor and printer. . What all input devices have in common is that they need to encode (convert) some kind of information into data that can be processed by the computer's digital system. . Output devices on the other hand, decode data into information that is understood by the computer user. . In this sense, a digital computer system is an example of a data processing system. . This process consists basically of three phases: Entry, Processing and Exit. . We understand by entry the entire information feeding procedure, which in turn will be processed (processing phase) and after that, the answers are passed to the user (output).

qas.question: . What are the most common input devices on modern personal computers?

paragraphs.context: . To connect all these devices there is a special support plate, the motherboard, which through bars, wires and sockets connects all devices. . Its function also includes connecting auxiliary boards that under-control the peripherals of input and output, such as the sound board (connects with the sound box), the video board (connects with the monitor), the network board (connects with the LAN) and the fax modem (connects with the telephone line). . It is noted that the bus between the components does not constitute a point-to-point connection; it can logically connect several components using the same set of wires. . The bus can use a serial interface or parallel interface. . Other additional equipment used in conjunction with the motherboard are the sink, a small fan to cool the processor, and the power source, responsible for the power supply of all computer components.

qas.question: . What distinguishes the computer from other machines?

paragraphs.context: . Instructions are represented on the computer as numbers - the code for "copying" could be 007, for example. . The particular set of instructions that a computer has is known as the computer machine language. . In practice, people do not write instructions directly in machine language but in a programming language, which is later translated into machine language through special programs such as interpreters and compilers. . Some programming languages are very close to machine language, such as assembly (low level language); on the other hand, languages such as Prolog are based on abstract principles and are quite distant from the details of machine operation (high level language). . The execution of instructions is just like reading a book. ̈ Although the person usually reads each word and line in sequence, it is possible that sometimes it returns to earlier points of the text of interest or passes non-interesting sessions. . Similarly, a computer that follows von Neumann's architecture executes each instruction sequentially, as they were stored in memory. . But, by special instructions, the computer can repeat or advance instructions until some condition is met. . This is called flow control and it is what allows the computer to perform tasks repeatedly without human intervention.

Programs are simply great lists of instructions for the computer to run, such as with data tables. ▪ Many computer programs contain millions of instructions, and many of these instructions are executed repeatedly. . A typical personal computer (in 2003) could execute about two to three billion instructions per second. . Computers do not have their extraordinary capacity due to a complex set of instructions. ̈ Although there are differences in CPU design with a greater number of instructions and more complex, computers execute millions of simple combined instructions, written by good "programmers". . These combined instructions are written to perform common tasks such as drawing a point on the screen. . Such instructions can then be used by other programmers.

qas.question: . How many instructions do computer programs have?

paragraphs.context: . Nowadays, many computers seem to run several programs at the same time, which is usually known as multitasking. . In fact, the CPU executes the instructions of a program for a short period of time and then switches to another program and executes some of its instructions. . This creates the illusion of several programs being executed simultaneously through sharing CPU time between programs. . This time sharing is normally controlled by the operating system. . In cases where the computer has two processing cores, each core processes program information, thus reducing processing time.

paragraphs.context: . The trainee is a professional at the beginning of his career. . The internship (from the Latin term internship by the French internship) is commonly provided by students , in companies or public departments, aiming at professional improvement in their area of study. . The contract is concluded between the student and the borrower, with the intervention of the educational institution, which must ensure that the contract is faithfully fulfilled. . Generically, it can also characterize a training period within companies, offered to individuals without mediation of educational institutions. . The function of the internship is to offer practical knowledge of professional functions. . It enables students to have an empirical contact with the theoretical subjects that are passed to them in the classroom. . It is the understanding, now consolidated by educators, that the theory, without practice, is incomplete, impairing immediate access to the labour market. . The internship aims to overcome this problem.

qas.question: . What does the internship allow?

paragraphs.context: . In Brazilian Legislation, the student internship is governed by Law No. 11,788 , of September 25, 2008. . and does not set up a job relationship. ̈ Although they do not have the rights to work, trainees have some rights, such as the receipt of a scholarship (if stipulated), the fulfilment of a pre-fixed hourly load, and the realization of compulsory insurance against accidents beyond 30 days paid of withdrawal after 1 year of internship. . Because of the ease in hiring an intern, and the complete absence of social charges, the internship is often used in fraud to the established regulations, serving as a means for informal work.

paragraphs.context: . The internship contract, in Brazilian law, aims to regulate a link between the contractor and the contractor. . The internship seeks educational complementation in higher and technical courses. . It is not considered by law to be a legal employment relationship. . The educational training of the service provider is sought with the internship. . This hiring has suffered criticism, because it allows some employers to defraud the spirit of the law, using the worker in normal activity in exchange for a scholarship to meet transportation and food expenses and not having all the social security and labor protection due to the employee. . Thus, when the real practice of simple less costly use of the labor force, without any educational gain for the student, will be seen, there will be transmutation of the species to that of the employment bond.

paragraphs.context: . According to the dictionary Aurélio, the monograph is the thorough study in order to exhaust a certain topic relatively restricted . . Another definition, based on the presentation by Umberto Eco, for example, in how a monograph is made refers to texts from thirty to two hundred pages written during a discipline or course by one or more people, on a topic related to the studies in which it should be deepened. . According to its purposes, the monograph is constructed from numerous rules that basically aim at the best treatment of the idea or subject treated as well as generate a certain homogeneity in relation to the methodology used for its creation. . This is based on facts or concepts, and the subject must be grounded so that a scientific or philosophical coherence and relevance can be obtained. . To this end, the monograph needs to be drawn from the existing base in bibliographies, which will base it or from practical scientific research results, as a way of presenting, rationalizing and discussing these methods.

answers.text: the thorough study in order to exhaust a certain topic relatively restricted

paragraphs.context: . In the United States, the term Professor is reserved only for individuals who teach at higher education institutions ( college or university ). . Teachers of elementary or high school are called Teachers. . In addition to the teaching itself, professors in American universities devote themselves mainly to research activities, including the guidance of graduate students. . In general, the academic degree of doctor (Ph.D. or equivalent) is required for entry into the professor's career at the American universities at the initial level of Assistant Professor (Assistant Professor). After a few years, an Assistant Professor may be promoted to Associate Professor and subsequently Full Professor. . A small number of full teachers who stand out for their research activities are named Distinguished Teachers (or Endowed Teachers), meaning that they are now holding a personal chair (personal chair) designated by a specific name (usually the name of the sponsor, natural or legal person, who financed/finances the chair).

paragraphs.context: . In several European countries, for example France and Germany, the title of teacher is also reserved in universities only for senior teachers. . In general, is required several years of professional or academic experience after completion of the PhD for an individual to qualify for an Qualification.

answers.text: is required several years of professional or academic experience

The area of Computer Science at UFMS had its ing point in 1987 , with the implementation of the Bachelor's Course in Computer Science, at the time Department of Mathematics at UFMS. . With the implementation of the course, more teachers in the area were hired and, with the growth of the group, the Department of Computation and Statistics (DCT) of the Federal University of Mato Grosso do Sul (UFMS) was created in October 1992, as a result of a subdivision of the then Department of Mathematics of UFMS.

Complementary activities of the Computer Science course, as an integral part of the curriculum, include extraclass activities relevant to the training of the student of the aforementioned course , and has a time load of 102 hours. . This Regulation applies to all students of the Computer Science course from the second semester of 2016. . Activities should be carried out throughout the course, and can be done in any of the semesters attended by the student. . Among the activities that can be used to complete the workload of Complementary Activities are: Participation in scientific events (seminars, symposiums, congresses, technological weeks and conferences), whether as a listener or presenter; teaching monitoring; team members of teaching projects approved by competent body; team members of extension projects approved by competent body; team members of research projects approved by competent body; non-mandatory internships; scientific initiation activities; publication of scientific works; participation in collegiate bodies; participation in courses relevant to the area, whether as a listener or a minister; disciplines taught as curriculum enrichment; participation in training and specific activities as a member of the voting board in the elections; response to the questionnaire of the student of the UFMS's Evaluation Committee; or other activities to be evaluated by the Course College.

answers.text: extraclass activities relevant to the training of the student of the aforementioned course

Participation in scientific events must be proven by means of the certificate of participation which must contain, mandatory, the name of the event, the name of the participant, the place, the date on which it was held, the time charge and the signature of the person responsible for the event . .
